content:
my problems with Thunderbird are more complex.

  1. 1 The user interface is ambiguous. Sometimes you quit an e-mail via the status banner sometimes via the cross in the upper right corner.
  • I never can find how to alter delete or add adresbooks on my Synology server
  • Altering appointments is impossible
  • moving to a dat is impossible 9only via work around a detected
  • complete lack of documentation where I can find answers
  • This way Thunderbird cost me hours, so not say days.

Despite I hate Microsoft and believe in applications like Thunderbird I'm seriously thinking of return into outlook or office 365. Thunderbird is not a religion but just a tool

content: Did you already look up Settings > Calendar > Reminders > Reminder Defaults > Default Snooze Length?
creator: Mapenzi

content: @Mapenzi thanks for your response. AFAIK that setting is for the default snooze length when manually deferring a reminder. I'm looking for a way for the alert sound to not keep repeating when I don't touch it at all. Unless that setting does double duty for both purposes? I'll try it out and see.

The Thunderbird setup may have downloaded to your default folder to download to instead of giving a prompt on where to download it. https://www.thunderbird.net/download/

The donation is a optional support and not required in order to download Thunderbird.

content:
Try this:

  1. exit thunderbird and copy the permissions.sqlite and content-prefs.sqlie files elsewhere
  2. now, restart thunderbird and click to settings>privacy&security and click the exceptions button and adjust as desired for the temporary restrictions
  3. at end of the temporary period, exit thunderbird and copy the backed up files back and then restart thunderbird
creator: davidsk

content: More information is needed. Did only messages disappear from folders you had created in Local Folders or did the folders disappear, too? Did you rename folders in your Local Folders?
creator: Mapenzi

content:
This is not a problem. if the accounts are POP, you would need to coordinate somewhat, but that would be only concern. If account is IMAP, thee is nothing to be concerned about. If using Windows, these steps will copy to new pc:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This WILL prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk
